awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Taming Convergence and Delay in Stochastic Network Optimization with Hessian Information
awd_abstract_narration:
With the rapid integration of massive amounts of data and new network devices, today's network infrastructures are being stretched to their limits. As a result, recent years have witnessed a critical need for developing fast-converging distributed stochastic network control and optimization algorithms to increase throughput and reduce delay. This research program addresses the challenge of distributed control and optimization for next generation complex network systems, where the rapidly changing network states (e.g., network topologies, channel states, queueing states, etc.) necessitate fast-convergence and low-delay in distributed optimization algorithms. Based on the investigator's recent research on network control and optimization that leverages second-order Hessian information (SOHI), this research will develop a series of new distributed algorithmic techniques that offer orders of magnitudes improvements in both convergence speed and queueing delay compared to the traditional approaches, while attaining the same provable network-utility optimality. 

Specifically, the investigator?s research tasks in this project are organized around three inter-related research thrusts that exploit different degrees of SOHI: i) Heavy-ball-based joint congestion control and multi-path routing (partial SOHI); ii) Primal-dual interior-point second-order congestion control and multi-path routing (full SOHI); and iii) SOHI-based distributed control and optimization algorithm designs. This research project takes an integrated and holistic approach that draws techniques from areas of mathematical modeling, optimization theory, control theory, queueing theory, and stochastic analysis. The research project will not only advance the knowledge in the algorithmic design for next generation complex networks, but will also serve a critical need in the general networking research community by exploring new frontiers in SOHI-based network control and optimization.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, our goal is to develop an analytical foundation for low-delay and fast-converging distributed network control and optimization based on second-order Hessian information (SOHI). The proposed research will not only advance the knowledge in the design of communication networks but will also serve a critical need in the general communications and signal processing research communities by exploring a cross-layer understanding of communications networks through a unified research program that consists of the development of tractable theoretical models, exploration of theoretical performance bounds and capacity limits, and the development of distributed algorithms. The proposed research aims to fill the void and contribute to an exciting second-order network control and optimization paradigm. The proposed research will support the communications, networking, and signal processing communities and the general public by facilitating the development of SOHI-based network protocols with substantially increased network performance. To that end, we will focus our research efforts along the following three interrelated thrust areas that exploit different degrees of SOHI: 1) momentum-based joint computing-networking (partial SOHI); 2) primal-dual second-order joint computing-networking control (full SOHI); and 3) SOHI-based distributed computing-networking algorithm design.

The lifetime of this award can be roughly divided into three stages. In the first stage of the award, we focus on developing fast-converging and low-delay joint congestion control and scheduling algorithms for single-hop and multi-hop networks, which are targeting at the higher layers in the protocol stack. Representative works in this stage include “Heavy-Ball” and “Nesterovian” joint congestion control and scheduling algorithms, both of which leverage momentum information in cross-layer design to accelerate the convergence speed of joint congestion control and scheduling, which entails high-throughput and low-delay. In addition, we also showed that the use of higher-order momentum information can continue to improve the delay performance. Based on these momentum-based approaches, we further investigated the impacts of limited channel state information on congestion control and scheduling. We showed that there is a “phase transition” phenomenon of the networking performance in terms of the channel state information accuracy.

In the second stage of this project, we investigated the medium access control layer and considered low-overhead uplink scheduling algorithms for specific physical layer technologies (e.g., massive MIMO, also known as massive multi-antenna systems), which is important for supporting a large class of applications with different physical layer technologies that call for efficient joint congestion control and scheduling optimization. Specifically, we characterized the capacity outer bound of these different physical layers subject to their unique constraints. The insights obtained from our proposed algorithms allow us to develop an efficient and low-overhead joint congestion control and scheduling algorithm with different levels of SOHI to satisfy the unique physical layer constraints with theoretical performance guarantees.

In the third stage of this project, with the rise of machine learning and artificial intelligence during this project period, our research gradually evolved toward studying related distributed, federated, and decentralized optimization and control problems still over single- and multi-hop networks, but with applications gearing more toward a variety of machine learning paradigms. The paradigms of distributed and federated learning are based on single-hop networks, while the paradigm of decentralized learning is based on multi-hop networks. In each learning paradigm, we have further considered a large class of optimization problems, including finite-sum or expectation minimization, min-max, and bilevel optimization. In federated learning, we have focused on developing fast-converging algorithmic techniques that work well under both system and data heterogeneity. We have incorporated momentum and variance reduction (partial SOHI) techniques and bilevel Hessian-approximation (full SOHI) to accelerate the convergence rate of the proposed algorithms, which further imply low sample and communication complexities. Similar momentum, variance reduction, and bilevel Hessian-approximation techniques are also developed for fully decentralized learning problems, which also significantly reduces the convergence rates and sample-communication complexities for solving these problems.
